scoring_variance_drivers: Quarterback volatility: several QBs swung matchups with large deviations (e.g., Josh Allen +17.93 in Week 1; Patrick Mahomes ranged from +6.21 to -6.65 across weeks).
D/ST and kicker outliers were decisive in multiple matchups (Vikings D/ST 32.0 Week 3; Chase McLaughlin 20.0 Week 3; Brandon Aubrey 22.0 Week 2).
Bench management created frequent swing outcomes — multiple teams left 15+ and 20+ point bench performances unused across weeks.

notable_close_games.matchup: Here Comes McBride @ World of Hurts (Week 3)
Here Comes McBride @ D.J. Chark Week (Week 2)
notable_close_games.margin_note: Several single-digit and sub-10 margins across Week 1-3; bench decisions would have flipped multiple outcomes.

common_themes: Repeatedly impactful bench decisions: teams frequently left high-scoring players (QBs, WRs, TEs) inactive and lost or narrowly won as a result.
Defenses and kickers have produced outsized weekly variance relative to projections and were often the difference in matchups.
No team has separated in the standings; a large cluster of 2-1 teams produces an early league logjam where points-for is already an important tiebreaker.

notable_trends: Very high scoring overall (highest points for in league).
Huge single-week D/ST return (Vikings D/ST 32.0 in Week 3) and big Jalen Hurts / Courtland Sutton outputs fueled the scoring surge.
Bench-management cost: Mark Andrews produced 24.1 from the bench in Week 3 (unused).
Strong rushing production has driven wins (Jonathan Taylor: 28.5 Week 2; 31.3 Week 3).
QB variance impacted Week 2 (Josh Allen underperformed) but the ground game offset those swings.
Has benefitted from large single-player weeks and remains among top scoring teams.
Week 3 blowout (130.22) highlighted the team's upside when Garrett Wilson and special teams (Chase McLaughlin 20.0) hit.
Bench depth has produced but often remained unused (Michael Pittman Jr. 16.3 left on bench Week 3).
Kicker and D/ST spikes (Chase McLaughlin, Steelers D/ST) have materially altered matchup outcomes in team's favor.
Explosive WR weeks (Amon-Ra St. Brown 34.7, Ja'Marr Chase 29.5 in Week 2) produced a big Week 2 total (138.64) but Week 3 blowout loss exposed defensive/consistency issues.
Season shows high ceiling but also vulnerability to one-week collapses; points-against currently high due to one lopsided loss (to Gronk Week 3).
Left notable bench scoring unused in Week 3 (Bhayshul Tuten, Elic Ayomanor earlier contributed from bench).

team_trends.team: I Know Exactly What I’m Doing
notable_trends: QB volatility has been a net positive when Caleb Williams started/produced (bench 24.2 Week 1; started 29.12 Week 3).
Week 2 outlier scoring from kicker and TE (Brandon Aubrey 22.0; Juwan Johnson 13.4) contributed to large win.
CeeDee Lamb's zero in Week 3 was a major outlier but team overcame it via QB and defense performance.
Started 2-0 through Week 2 but suffered a heavy Week 3 loss (81.06) that lowered points-per-week.
Performance has been inconsistent due to RB volatility (Derrick Henry big in Week 1 then low Week 2) and several WR/RB underperformances.
Bench management cost in multiple weeks (Jauan Jennings 17.4 left inactive Week 2; Ollie Gordon II TD from bench Week 3 for opponent).
Very high scoring despite 1-2 record — this team leads lower-record teams in points for (tremendous offense weeks).
Bench explosion weeks (Rome Odunze 28.3 bench Week 2; Jake Ferguson 14.7 bench Week 3) indicate depth but also missed lineup optimization.
Close losses and leaving Jared Goff / other QBs on bench in prior weeks cost opportunities to convert points to wins.
Struck a big Week 3 win behind David Montgomery's breakout (28.9) and strong bench scoring (Hunter Henry 25.0 left on bench Week 3 for owner to consider).
Has struggled earlier with bench decisions — Jared Goff produced 33.96 on the bench in Week 2, an obvious missed start.
Offense can pop when the run game hits; otherwise inconsistent due to QB/WR variance.
Patrick Mahomes produced in Weeks 1-2 but regressed Week 3; QB downgrade impacted offensive ceiling (13.16 Week 3).
TE production (Dalton Kincaid Week 3) and RB contributions (Kenneth Walker) have helped, but WRs and QB volatility limited consistency.
Left bench pieces (George Pickens 15.3) unused in critical weeks.
High offensive totals across weeks but 1-2 record — has had both big bench/starting outputs and costly underperformances (Malik Nabers big drop Week 3).
Buccaneers D/ST and RB usage (Omarion Hampton) provided key results in the narrow Week 3 win.
Roster volatility: intermittent WR busts and occasional D/ST/kicker uplifts.
Started 2-0 but Week 3 collapse dropped points-for to the lowest among 2-1 teams.
Large missed opportunity from benching Zay Flowers (24.6 left on bench Week 2) and A.J. Brown (bench Week 3 with 19.9).
High variance at WR/TE spots and some poor QB outings (Dak Prescott had a very low 7.82 in Week 1 and 12.04 Week 2).
Only 0-3 team — offense has underperformed most weeks and points-against is already elevated due to lopsided losses.
QB/WR pairing inconsistencies (Joe Burrow underperformed Week 1; Jordan Love underperformed in Week 3 start) contributed to lack of wins.
Some bench players produced (Ricky Pearsall, Khalil Shakir) but were insufficient to change outcomes.

player_level_trends_affecting_teams.trend: Escalating impact — modest Week 1, then huge back-to-back touchdown weeks (28.5 Week 2, 31.3 Week 3) that won matchups for his owner.

teams_impacted: I Know Exactly What I’m Doing
player_level_trends_affecting_teams.trend: Produced from bench Week 1 (24.2) and then started Week 3 with a large 29.12 — clear positive QB swing when active for that roster.
Strong early weeks (26.02, 22.08) followed by a drop to 13.16 in Week 3 — QB volatility impacted D.J. Chark Week's ability to close matches.
Produced 24.1 from the bench in Week 3 — a major unused TE performance that would have increased an already large team total further.
Kickers and defenses have shown high week-to-week variance and have been matchup-deciding (examples: Brandon Aubrey 22.0 Week 2; Vikings D/ST 32.0 Week 3; Chase McLaughlin 20.0 Week 3).

notable_owner_behaviors.behavior: Repeated benching of high-scoring available players
examples: Goff And Running left Jared Goff on the bench Week 2 while Goff scored 33.96 — largest single-game bench delta noted.
Multiple owners left 20+ point bench performances unused across weeks (Justin Fields 29.52 Week 1; Rome Odunze 28.3 Week 2; Mark Andrews 24.1 Week 3).
Puka Puka left Zay Flowers (24.6) on bench in Week 2 and later saw underperformance from starters at the same positions.

notable_owner_behaviors.behavior: Starting speculative defenses/kickers that massively outperformed
examples: I Know Exactly What I’m Doing benefited from Brandon Aubrey 22.0 Week 2 and Seahawks D/ST 17.0 Week 3.
Gronk for my johnson's Vikings D/ST 32.0 Week 3 swung a matchup by a very large margin.

notable_owner_behaviors.behavior: High variance QB starts vs benches
examples: Teams rotated or left QBs inactive with high weekly variance (Justin Herbert on bench Week 1 for Gronk; Jared Goff benched Week 2).
Caleb Williams was benched Week 1 but started and produced Week 3, demonstrating how QB lineup choices changed outcomes.

playoff_picture_top6_after_week3.format: 6 teams make playoffs (by record, then head-to-head, then points for)

projected_qualifiers.notes: Leads 2-1 cluster on points-for and has shown high ceiling weeks; currently projected into playoff field based on record then PF.
Strong multi-week rushing production and top points-for among 2-1 teams; occupies a playoff spot by record + PF.
High-scoring Week 3 put this team into the upper half of the 2-1 cluster for PF tie-breaker.
Large Week 2 exploded points total; tied with Baker on PF closely and held into projected playoff positions.

projected_qualifiers.team: I Know Exactly What I’m Doing
projected_qualifiers.notes: Strong QB/DEF weeks and consistent scoring keep this team within the top-6 projected qualifiers.
Lowest points-for among the seven 2-1 teams; currently occupies the sixth projected spot by record, but sits on the bubble due to lower PF.

teams_on_bubble.notes: Also 2-1 but lowest points-for among 2-1 teams; would be the first team excluded from a 6-team playoff field using PF tiebreaker.

notes_on_tiebreakers: Seven teams share the top record cluster at 2-1 after Week 3; with only six playoff spots available the points-for tiebreaker is already decisive for inclusion/exclusion.
Head-to-head has been limited among the 2-1 group; therefore points-for is the practical differentiator at this early stage.

summary_observations_and_watch_points_fo: Bench and roster activation decisions have been the single most visible behavioral trend — multiple matchups flipped on unused bench performances. Track owners who continue to leave top-performers on bench.
Defenses and kickers have produced several matchup-winning weeks; owners who identify and start these units at the right time have reaped outsized benefits.
The standings are tightly clustered. With seven teams at 2-1, small weekly swings (a single 20+ point bench player or a D/ST/kicker outlier) will reshuffle the early playoff picture quickly.

Watchlist players/roles that have repeatedly impacted outcomes: Jonathan Taylor (OHHHH), Caleb Williams (I Know), and high-ceiling TEs/bench QBs who have alternated between starting and bench roles producing large deltas.
